article:
In mathematics, the elements of a set A may be indexed or labeled by means of a
set J that is on that account called an 'index set'. The indexing consists of a
surjective function from J onto A and the indexed collection is typically called
an [[indexed family|(indexed) family]], often written as
(A j) jâJ .

In computational complexity theory and cryptography, an index set is a set for
which there exists an algorithm I that can sample the set efficiently; i.e., on
input 1 n, I can efficiently select a poly(n)-bit long element from
the set.  {{cite book
  | title= Foundations of Cryptography: Volume 1, Basic Tools
  |last= Goldreich |first= Oded |year= 2001 |publisher= Cambridge University
  Press |isbn= 0-521-79172-3 }}
